title: Multinationals, Institutions and Innovation in Europe
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Multinationals, Institutions and Innovation in Europe," aims to investigate the location strategies of multinational enterprises (MNEs) and their territorial impacts in Europe. With MNEs contributing over US$16 trillion to the global economy and accounting for more than a quarter of the world GDP, understanding their behavior is crucial for policymakers and researchers.

The project will address existing gaps in the literature by examining the relationships between MNEs, institutions, and innovation in Europe. By analyzing data on FDI outflows from developing economies, which reached $426 billion in 2012, the project will shed light on the changing patterns of global investment flows. Notably, global outflows accounted for 31% of the total in 2012, compared to 16% in 2007, highlighting the increasing importance of MNEs in the global economy.

Through a combination of quantitative analysis and qualitative case studies, the project will provide valuable insights into the factors driving MNE location decisions and their implications for innovation and economic development in Europe. The research findings will offer policymakers and stakeholders essential tools for decision-making and policy formulation in a rapidly changing global economic landscape.

With MNEs contributing to over US$16 trillion in value added and accounting for more than a quarter of the world GDP, understanding their behavior and effects on the regional economy is crucial. Despite the significant role of MNEs in the global economy, there are gaps in the existing literature regarding their location strategies and territorial impacts.

This project seeks to fill these gaps by conducting in-depth research on the relationship between MNEs, institutions, and innovation in Europe. By examining the patterns of foreign direct investment (FDI) outflows from developing economies and the changing global outflows percentages from 2007 to 2012 (16% to 31%), the project aims to provide valuable insights for policymakers and stakeholders. The ultimate goal is to develop policy-making tools that can help European countries attract and benefit from MNEs while ensuring sustainable economic growth and innovation.

Through a combination of quantitative analysis and qualitative research methods, this project will contribute to the academic literature on MNEs and provide practical recommendations for policymakers in Europe.
